bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ignacio Alvare, November 26, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Alvare a reprint of his yellow fever article and notes that it is the beginning of his attempts to honor Finlay's work as well as that of the yellow fever board.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ignacio Alvare, November 26, 1941
div1.opener:
Enclosures 1)reprint
2) Pogolotti map - large
3) Alvare photo
4) my photo of tree & Moran
5) small map of Havana
Copy to Moran
November 26, 1941
Dr. Ignacio Alvare
Calle 9, No. 304
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Doctor Alvare:
div1.p:
I enclose a reprint of an address I gave last June when Dr. Walter
Reed's daughter unveiled a painting honoring the conquerors of yellow fever. It
is merely the beginning for me of a campaign to give due honor to Dr. Finlay as
well as to the members of the American Yellow Fever Board.

I am now writing an article on “The Location of Camp Lazear” and
would appreciate just one more item of information from you.

When you took the photograph of the little house and tree (enclosed)
in 1926 do you remember whether the little building faced squarely the railroad
track or not? The tree in your photograph is undoubtedly the one in my photo-
graph recently surrounded by the little memorial fence and marked by the sign.
Allowing for changes due to the growth of roots and branches during the lapse of
14 years since your photograph was taken it is obviously the same tree. From the
arrangement of its branches and especially from the arrangement of its base and
roots which spread out in an individualistic manner with three roots visible and
a hollow between roots 2 and 3 (compare the two photographs) I am sure that one
can identify the tree in your photo as the one which is in mine. But I am most
anxious to know in what direction the little building in your photograph faced.
This building is of course no longer there. But using your old photograph and
estimating from the roots and branches of the tree in relationship to the little
building in your photograph Mr. Moran and I determined that the building must have
faced squarely the railroad track about 75 feet away. In other words the little
building faced almost east (east by a little north). Am I correct in this? I
feel that it is important for me to know this and to have you tell me for sure.

I enclose a map of Reparto Padre Zamora with the site of your photograph
noted thereon in red, also the direction of the compass which you can check from
the small map of Havana enclosed. If you cannot tell me for sure from a perusal
of the maps and photographs in which direction the building faced would you be
good enough to drive out to the site at your leisure (if you have any!) and check
it actually on the spot? Perhaps then your memory will permit you to give me the
exact information.

I hate to bother you thus but I am very anxious to have your statement
on this. I hope to write a monograph on the whole subject and I precisely do
appreciate your aid in locating precisely the various sites concerned. I would appreciate it
if you will return the maps and photographs when you are through with them. Thank
you very much.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
